p: 11. An appearance can become a semblance. The rash is indeed a genuine phenomenon insofar as it shows up as a rash. But the rash [= the third sense of phenomenon in the chart above] can privatively become a “semblance” [the second sense of phenomenon in the chart] if it announces something other than the disease that causes it. For example, let us say someone blushes out of embarrassment. If we take the redness of his cheeks not as a manifestation of embarrassment but rather as the symptom of a fever (and thus of an underlying disease), the red cheeks would be a semblance.
